xMTUN7ZU7fYNivDcpwDZDA.text: The second Kanada-Ya branch also did not disappoint. The queue was 2 hours long for 50% off food (ends this Friday 4/12/15). It was nice seeing the owner with his red headcloth standing at the door as well!Karage is a good item to order, juicy, succulent fried chicken. They don't serve this in the first branch on St Giles. 3 pieces of chicken per dish.Green tea comes in little red or black teapots (one pot per person)Charshu Men comes with so much pork and is for those who likes a non spicy soup base.I got the Gekikara which is pretty spicy, comes with charshu and also minced meat. Eggs must be ordered separately for Charshu Men and Gekikara and they are worth the order. Went for hard noodles but the star of the show here aren't the ramen, but the meat and eggs :)Service is pretty good. Happy days.

W0k0wA1urnU_UW4mpb8o5w.text: This is some of the best Tonkotsu-based Ramen I had in my life. It had very deep flavor and almost palpable thickness to it, the pork slices were silky-soft, and the egg was just cooked while still being runny. If it needs to be translated to Bay Area dialect, on the level of Ramen Dojo minus the long lines. I would still give a nod to Orenchi, but there one could as well wait for the title character from Becket's play. As for the price - this part of London is not exactly known for bargains, so my advice is either to clench one's teeth and pay, or go to Pret-a-Manger and  (almost) not pay. If there a way to get both quality and price, please post it on Yelp or call your doctor, because it may lead to an unsafe drop in blood pressure

Y5B5Rc6irARpKCCTYMopuQ.text: This is the hidden gem of ramen places. Absolutely delicious 18 hour pork broth (non-pork, inc veg option available). It's worth the price and slightly reduced compared to other ramen places around London. Highly recommend if you want the best ramen in London.

omf8DEQclDiGw5az-E-gfg.text: A short review for me.This is the reason we all live in London.  Utterly sensational. The vegetarian (mushroom broth) ramen was absolutely not a second best option.  Desperate to find a reason to go back - missed out the other day because it closes at 8!!!

n3SVMUgOTy-W7P8iCXO8Rw.text: Love their ice cream. They are the only one do black sesame ice cream so far and I think is really tasty and yummy. And they do half half ice cream! Only this branch do ice cream so when ever you come here must order their ice cream for dessert.

uVwyvC0B0mixrm5W6DDF_w.text: We've eaten ramen all over Japan and New York.  This place is the real deal!

NMc_ymQ60Dsbp8aEHqqxYA.text: This branch is bigger than the St Giles location making it way more pleasant to sit inside and less rushed. The tonkotsu is very good, but maybe a bit heavier than most are used to. The chashu don was really tasty - lots of umami. The meat was very tender and the rice very flavorful. Highly recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Super yummy chashu don!
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Tonkotsu with egg

8YjD-YcdTnzbWHsF1fgHKg.text: Ramen was not good unfortunately and i was really craving it. Noodles were kinda like using italian spaghetti in ramen broth...weird. Fyi: i traveled to japan annually for a while and have a good reference point. Pork was hard, again, not using proper technique. It should be melt in your mouth, but this needed chewing. Broth was actually pretty decent, i got the spicy one. The truffle edamame was really bad. I enjoy edamame to the point i make it at home (super easy). These were overcooked which meant the skin doesnt stay in form and the beans are way too soft so overall texture very bad. Truffle salt was uneven. I actually didnt even finish this. Coke with ice was the highlight, as was the service. They were cheerful and attentive.

oyH8Imlx-BI57MjibV_aTA.text: It's slightly bigger than the other Kanada-Ya but still pretty small. I like the service (they were all very kind) and of course the ramen. Honestly, I like the Shoryu ramen the best in London so far but Kanada-Ya has to be the next favorite! The broth is great the noddles, not so much. But I think Kanada-Ya has the best eggs. It's a little cool when first served and you must take it together with the hot broth! So good!!

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Tonkotsu ramen

9V7hsXZvx7YkiMdYIpMq8Q.text: Um, no.Not sure how this was rated as the top 50 ramen of Japan because this is nothing like Japan. I think this was the ramen shop that used non-ramen noodles. What is that about?? The yuzu ramen was so full of arugula all you could taste was arugula leaves. We went to the other ramen shop after this across the street to see if that was any better but that wasn't either. I thought London would know better but I think they are catering to a non-Asian palette.

UwtSQQfeYZQj_zl8IiEG9Q.text: I tried truffle ramen which was really good and special. I really think this shop is much better than shoryu ramen. This is the best so far in my London trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom

SQqIhelcQVCbIMrDqgQf7A.text: This place is tiny but the Ramen has to be the best I've had in a very long time!They also have a truffle option which you can smell the instant you walk through the door.It's convenient located near Piccadilly station so you can stop by after a shop and they do take reservation which I recommend you do especially on the weekends.  We did a walk in on a Monday afternoon about 40mins before close and got a seat straight away.Get to tonkatsu X, karage chicken and the small chashu pork small place.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Tonkatsu X

lY_fg0L7pYaIUJH3SS-moA.text: Way too pricy for what you are getting! Yes it is great ramen, but not a £14 ramen; and certainly not a £20 dinner.The truffle Ramen was quite nice admittedly but the portion was just small in general.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Oishi! Yum!
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Original ramen
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Truffle ramen

sHLKCSTeo3zBzmMixK16vA.text: Possibly the best Japanese ramen shop that I have ever experienced. I had the Gekikara, which included 'hard' noodles in a pork bone broth spicy tan-tan minced pork belly chashu, wood ear fungus, spring onion, seaweed, bean sprouts!! It was super spicy for my palette. They ran out of their infamous Misha soft serve dessert the evening that I came by 8pm. I'm planning to go back for more.  The service was incredible. I loved the diverse staff that helmed from Romania, Hong Kong... best noodle house in London hands down!

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Gekikara served with hard noodles as recommended by the chef! Super delicious and spicy

jckeIIU4pEakZL-QDNLNrw.text: original tonkutsu ramen £10.50 (with regular noodles) - the cloudy broth had quite a strong and a deep porky flavour to it. The v-shape of the bowl was deceiving as to how much it held. I was surprised that it had more than I thought. I liked it a lot but I thought it could be better if the broth was served steaming hot and the slices of pork belly were not cold. spicy yuzu ramen £12.00 (with regular noodles) - this was my favourite, not least because I do like spicy food. While the original tonkutsu can be porky, the citrus tang of the yuzu cuts through the porkiness of this broth and as you plough through the bowl, it gets spicier and spicier. The heat is gentle but slowly kicking in and though it is spicy, it does not numb the tastebuds. The meat served in this bowl has less fat but again the meat was cold and the broth could have been a tad warmer.chicken karaage £4.00 - boneless crispy chicken that is not too oily, not too greasy and not dried out from the frying. The mayonnaise on the side was a nice touch - although the fried chicken did not need it - but just not quite enough for all the pieces. matcha swirl ice-cream £4.00 - after a bowlful of noodles with one side dish, this portion of matcha ice-cream was just right to share between two but I stongly urge you not to. It was delicious; not too sweet and did not quickly melt away. Rated my second best matcha ice-cream in London so you would understand why I was so selfish as to not share. Kanada-ya does holds the spot as my favourite ramen place in London. It was a good, satisfying meal at a reasonable price. With the dessert, I felt that my meal in Kanada-ya was complete and wholesome. Looking forward to going back soon!

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. fried chicken
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. matcha swirl
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. original tonkutsu

74DD8rPLE7AB5lKORquqUg.text: Overall really great and worth waiting. Want to try the Tonkotsu and the Tonkotsu X next time.+ Super rich tonkotsu broth, almost chalky in texture and a bit overpowering for me. ~ Noodles at hard (their recommendation) were a bit too much for me, but definitely very unique.+ Egg is spot on~ Pork collar was a bit cold (intended?) but super soft/melt-in-your mouth

abCONQcbJz3FvrFQTNBb2Q.text: I went to Kanada-Ya yesterday with my flatmates because they were keen to try their truffle Ramen. We booked a table easily online (which is great because so many places just make you queue!). The staff was friendly and nice throughout the meal and we never lacked for anything (water, condiments...).Now, the interesting part, the one you are all waiting for... The food! Truffle ramen (£14) smells like truffle even from across the table. Very apetising! Both my flatmates chose to have it with an egg as a topping - it was delicious (yes I did taste it). The egg especially was amazing apparently (I did not taste it sadly, but they ordered an extra one so I guess it was worth it!). I ate a Gekikara (£13). Spicy, flavourful, with hard noodles (you can choose if you want the noodles hard, extra hard, medium or soft). The special thing with the Gekikara is the tantan minced pork (the ball you see on my bowl), which is soft and nice and spicy and tasty. Very good food. Tiny bit expensive for ramen, but that's the case (almost) everywhere in London and was to be expected so close to the centre. Also portions not huge - we had kaedama (extra noodles for £2).

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Truffle ramen
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Gekikara
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Gekikara (the ball in the middle is tantan minced pork, yummy)

kPnmo6lFL04GSdDSVZrdQg.text: Crunchy-fresh seaweed and beansprouts, flavoursome broth and delightful condiments on the side. This is a good-value spot for a satisfying ramen meal. Meanwhile the onigiri (Tamanishiki rice balls) were succulent but do not have much filling. Although not quite exceptional, it is evident that Kanada Ya does give due attention to presentation and taste, and is an enjoyable and convenient place to eat in the centre of London next to bustling Piccadilly Circus.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom

lD5mZb9wtYKjwBjkLa662Q.text: Having missed the 50% period I went in on Monday with a coworker. Traditional Japanese greeting and we were asked where we would like to sit. We chose a booth but you need to be careful, some of them are a little uneven when it comes to how much space between table and bench seat back, my coworker had plenty of room on her side, me? Not so much...However, we weren't here for the seats, we were here for the noodles and the noodles were great! No offer of thick or thin noodles, just how hard they are cooked. But the Tonkotsu ramen is great. Not that happy that egg is an additional extra but you do need to get it. Most places have it as standard unless you are getting a lunch special. Here, it's an optional extra. However the broth and noodles themselves are beautiful.We got the chicken karaage as well and this was a lot larger than expected. Hot succulent fried chicken served in a little metal bucket. We had to wait for it as the first one ended up on the floor while being delivered to us, but accidents happen. No big deal, they let us know immediately and everything was fine.I'd go again, it's a little expensive for lunch and there are SO many ramen shops around now (two in this little street alone). Maybe dinner, but like the other branch this gets SO busy.

mBgRkaGvtz1qS4_SyXuFLg.text: Firstly I think the fame has gone to Kanada-ya's head and unfortunately the quality has gone downhill especially at this new branch.  At dinner service on a Friday at 7 pm, when you'd expect them to be starting their busiest shift, we were advised they'd run out of the ni-tamago (egg which normally accompanies Tonkotsu ramen, but we'd have to pay for separately here!).  The noodles were really average, the broth too salty, and consistency thick and greasy compared to other Tonkotsu we have tried in London, and other cities including Tokyo. More importantly, the manager and staff were extremely rude and patronising.  When we were seated, they bluntly told us you are just going to have to share a table (with two other guests) as if we were a nuisance.  When we enquired later if we would have a friend join us (as there were two other empty tables), instead of simply saying no they told us they were cancelling our order and asked us to leave to table to stand outside - my friend being 8 months pregnant (!).  We said we'd stay instead and the manager look put out. In all my years of dining I've never experienced such appalling service. I'm afraid we will never return; there are much better ramen options in London.

-EtwfYIKQzrvOp6tHQh2Bw.text: I sampled the charshu ramen & karaage chicken on the second day of the soft launch at the long awaited second branch of kanada-ya.  The broth as expected is flavoursome and does not have the over rich pork taste at the first branch which some people found off putting.  The ramen comes with lots of slices of charshu but the egg needs to be ordered separately and definitely should be ordered, I ordered 2 eggs as they taste so good!  The amount of ramen, meat and eggs was so huge I struggled to finish and only managed to try a small piece of the tasty fried chicken side we ordered.Kanada-ya remains the best ramen specialist in London, the second branch is more spacious and takes bookings for groups of 6 or more otherwise be prepared for long queues!

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Black sesame & matcha soft serve
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Truffle ramen plus egg 14 + 2. 16 for ramen with very little meat is way too overpriced now especially as it's no longer the best!
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Karaage

eLUo1399pvDYX8BSB3KcDA.text: Wish I could give it 4.5. It's one of the best (if not the best) bowls of ramen in London so I've rounded it up to 5. I've eaten at Bone Daddies, Shoryu and Ippudo and only Ippudo can even come close. Love that you can request noodle hardness based on personal preference and that they have little help yourself dishes of mustard greens and pickled ginger at every table, reminds me of Japan. With the opening of this second branch of Kanada-Ya 6 months ago, it helps to alleviate the burden on their flagship (never not seen a line in front of it). The great thing about this one being so new, is that most people don't know about it. So, we were able to stroll in on a rainy Saturday at 7pm with no wait to get a booth large enough for 4, for the two of us. The seating is across two floors with some tables in the basement for approximately 20-30 and another 30 upstairs in square and round booths as well as counter seating. We had a look at the menu and decided to have the sake (salmon) onigiri (2 pieces for £4.25) along with our ramen. They came to the table warm (definite plus) and the rice was nicely cooked and the furikake added some additional umami to the onigiri. The salmon was good and I just wished there was more of it. Balanced ratio of rice to salmon for an onigiri, but I'm just greedy :)I decided to order the Gekikara (£13) which was served with spicy 'tan tan' style minced pork, pork belly chashu, wood ear fungus, seaweed and fresh spring onion. I also opted to add on a Hanjuku Egg (£2). Adam decided to get the Tonkotsu X (£10.50) which was promoted as only available in London and was a mix of their famous pork broth with a chicken broth and was served with pork belly chashu, wood ear fungus, seaweed and fresh spring onion. He ordered the addition of the egg as well. Service was quick and soon after we ordered, the bowls were in front of us. Great depth of flavor in the broth (key to any excellent ramen) and noodles cooked perfectly al dente (helps that you can pick based on your personal noodle firmness). I really enjoyed the addition of the minced pork in mine and the added kick from the spice. The egg was excellent, beautifully cooked with a slightly soft yolk. One of the most flavorful eggs I've had. I should have ordered two... or five. The chashu was cooked well with a good ratio of fat to meat. The pickled ginger was a nice addition to help cut the fat. We don't usually order dessert but the matcha soft serve was calling our names. It was a great way to end the meal - not overly sweet with an intense matcha flavor that I loved. Compared to what you get and pay at the other ramen places in London, Kanada-Ya is completely worth it. When I'm in the mood for ramen, here or Ippudo will be my only options worth considering.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Utensils, sesame seeds, garlic, pickled ginger and mustard greens
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Tonkotsu X (10.50) with addition of a hanjuku egg (2)
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Gekikara (13) with addition of a hanjuku egg (2)

FsTvlq7AG8anZXvVK8_6NA.text: I was excited to see a second branch of Kanada-Ya tucked away in Panton St. Haven't been to the original one and we were lucky on a Tuesday evening to get a table right away. Ordered the classic tonkotsu ramen, as it comes. The stock is thick and rich and not too salty which is good. The flavours I got from the broth were very unami, mushroomy with a porky base, even slightly truffle like.The noodles however were very fine diameter so a little insubstantial and the pork slices tender but a bit on the skimpy side.Portion size medium, not huge but the soup is pretty rich and so it was satisfying enough.Prices a bit on the steep side as they always are for ramen.Service was good and friendly.Overall good but not wowed is my summary. I like Bone Daddies better.

NzA2eDMcfvmPHQwToIDtxg.text: OK,  I'm gonna say it but this must be my favourite ramen place in London.  This this the sister branch which opened a few months ago... Tried to queue for the soft launch bit never made it as got way too hungry for it.. I love how the menus is short,  not over whelming.. Ramen was standard large and the special... I usually go for the large version and add an extra egg... Omg the egg.... Hold,  while I wipe that saliva off my chin... Thinking about this I think it should be ramen time soon...

9Qngkap7_WTs3jznKbmMmw.text: Although the service was good at this joint the food was not up to par. Tonkotsu was far too fatty with no option for less. Noodles were thinniest I've had anywhere which I did not enjoy. Broth was not piping hot on arrival.  Added chicken egg was great flavorful and perfect runny yolk. Karaage tasted refried-- avoid at all cost. Def would not return. It's unfortunate I didnt get a chance to try Ippudo, Bone Daddies or Tonkotsu.

ws_otT0YjkAZIVIYPeWtUg.text: I was crazy to wait 2 hours for a table in the cold and rain, all for 50% off for their new opening of their second London branch.By the time we got a seat they were sold Charshu Men assuming not enough charshu to go round! Instead we ordered the original and added the egg. The soup was nice with full of flavour but not too over powering.  The ramen has a choice of texture and opted for the regular. It was nicely cooked ramen which was not too soft. Only disappointment was the egg which was too salty. The charshu was cut too thick and felt the place next door was better!I tried the flaked salmon onigiri but the salmon was too salty. Even the rice was bland, the salty filling didn't help balance the flavour.Overall the ramen and broth waa good. But the seasoning on the egg and salmon was on the salty side (may be just that day?!). The service was good even so busy with a long queue outside

EHYKxjbYcY-V52pz2gH7hg.text: Their TRUFFLE RAMEN is the best ramen I've ever had!! Cute shop near Soho area. There can sometimes be a wait but we got lucky. Service was great - fast, friendly, kind. We ordered the salmon rice ball, toneki and truffle ramen. Toppings such as eggs are extra and you can choose your ramen firmness. Tonkatsu - super creamy broth!! The London version (Tonkatsu X) is less creamy. It was great and not super salty. Truffle Ramen - It came with a spoonful of truffle that you mix into the broth. It's so strong but absolutely amazing!! You can taste the truffle but it still keeps the flavor of your typical ramen broth. Noodles were great (hard) and decent portions. Rice balls - just alright. Salmon wasn't flavored at al it seemed like but the rice was good. It really lacked in comparison to the ramen. Would have loved to come back again just for this truffle ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom

evemNxG20KqbJIS9gXN7sw.text: The ramen is delicious. The vegetarian option has a Thick broth with some asparagus and seaweed. They also have some vegetarian specials and sticky rice options.  There can be a wait to get a table and it is not great at seating groups larger than 4/5 due to space.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom

ObSpKnmYVXSnQFAod6Z_rA.text: On my recent trip to London/Paris I became addicted to ramen and Kirin beer! This place was right around the corner from where we were staying and it consistently had a line out the door which made me think it must be good.  I was right! We waited in line for about 20 minutes and were seated at a table downstairs.  Pork bones are simmered for 18 hours to create the delicious tonkotsu broth. Bowls of this are then filled with thin wheat noodles cooked to your specification, from super-firm to super-soft (hard is the recommendation and what we had). I am going to have to look REALLY hard to find a place half as good as this at home.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom

Jn6x1mhsQhnwUp2rvtbelw.text: Tonkotsu X ramen soup was the best I've ever had.  The perfect broth. Our favorite meal in London.

yPzgx6BasIFgNgtAuvuckg.text: Despite the constant queue and small interior, Kanada-Ya is right at the top when it comes to ramen in London. To avoid the long wait, my friend and I came on a Sunday at 6:15pm. We were seated by 6:30pm and our orders were taken shortly after we sat down. For starters, we shared a karaage. This was alright. I felt that there was too much batter but the chicken was really tender. For my ramen, I usually go for the tonkotsu but wanted to try something different this time. I decided on the truffle tonkotsu and my friend got the regular tonkotsu and an egg (extra) for both of us. You can choose the level of firmness for your noodles and we both picked "hard" as recommended by the restaurant. The truffle tonkotsu definitely did not disappoint. The truffle flavor and scent were strong but I could still taste the creaminess of the tonkotsu broth. The pork was flavorful and had just the right amount of fattiness though I wished each piece was thicker! What I loved most was the heaping serve of scallions and the yolks of the tamago. They were flavorful and cooked perfectly - even though the egg is extra I highly recommend getting it! The only thing I wish could be better was the thickness and the texture of the noodles - the noodles were pretty thin even though we got "hard" noodles it still felt less than al dente.In terms of taste, Kanadaya is definitely my favorite ramen joint in London. I'll be back frequently!

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Truffle tonkotsu
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Karaage

MRjmu_l0tHM9r3LSIZYFLA.text: There are a few negatives about this place.... it's really small, the egg isn't included, the line of people waiting outside makes you feel like you need to rush, and they don't take reservations.However, even considering all of that, Kanada-Ya probably makes the best ramen in London.  The broth is rich and flavorful, and the noodles are cooked to your liking (although they recommend 'hard').  I ordered the Gekikara which was full of delicious spicy pork flavor.  Oh.. and the hanjuku egg? It's definitely the tastiest soft boiled egg I've ever had. Worth the extra £2.I literally woke up the next morning thinking about this ramen.  I can't wait to come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Gekikara ramen - highly recommend!!!!

z0K2-8T1kEKdu1-vVpWwgA.text: Great Ramen place in Haymarket. The soup was a little different than I'm used to in DC, but it was great. Will definitely go back next time I'm in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom

i-7BJBvhtDUK_gAolWci8Q.text: Ramen is a fast food and traditional shops are no larger than 100 sq. feet. Kanada-Ya's resembled most of that, except they have a little bit more space.Absolute authenticity in their soup, their noodles, and their service. What makes it extra traditional is that you can order Kaedama (替え玉) AKA more noodles that come after you finish your first bowl. Fun fact, not many ramen-ya outside of Japan actually offer that.

D6YQFX8Eb6IfAnlIXNflPA.text: I absolutely love this noodle house but boo to them today for running out of hanjuku eggs only one hour after opening.

gbDyVPSo3peUrc8NXWCm1A.text: Tiny starvation portions.  The pork is sliced wafer thin.  Hardly any noodles.  Can't understand why people line up outside to eat internment camp rations.  Ridiculous rip off.  Even Tokyo portions are larger.

WUgASLExlM-iwOyiYgsrRw.text: Came here with my sister and ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen (Pork bone broth, chashu pork belly, wood ear fungus, seaweed, spring onion), which was rich and savory. Broth was a bit too salty in my opinion, but still great and noodles were a nice consistency. The chashu pork belly was enjoyable, but not as tender as I would have liked. Overall, the ramen was without a doubt delicious, however I did not think it was anything special and NOT worth waiting almost an hour in line in the cold for.

hpwjmER1bePp9zl9TGscNA.text: Went for ramen right before closing time. They were able to put us at a shared table with another couple. We ordered the truffle edamame, gekikara ramen and spicy Yuzu ramen. We also got the sake sampler (which had 3 sweet sakes -don't order if you like drier sakes). The ramen and edamame were delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Gekikara
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Sake sampler
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Spicy yuzu ramen

Ht0kec7GTS_X0fjQyyk9HA.text: My favourite tonkotsu ramen place in London so far.Their broth is rich and thick, which is why I prefer the spicy pork meatball or the yuzu spicy versions which have spice and sourness to cut the creaminess.I heavily recommend the tori karaage (Japanese fried chicken) the hot crispiness contrasts well with the velvety broth.Our surprise discovery was the truffle edamame. The cheapest truffle treat I've seen in London, but packed with fragrance and flavour. I was very impressed with the combination. The truffles pair very well with the mild beans.We ordered the matcha green tea and the special ice cream. On this visit, the special was sesame and I must say I hugely preferred it over the matcha Ice cream.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Truffle edamame
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Matcha & sesame soft serves
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Spicy yuzu

DWZuvAHrLUAIJGCcWuPYXg.text: On my first night in London, I was looking for some comfort food and Kanada-Ya was close to where I was staying. There wasn't a queue as I went around 8pm and was quickly greeted and seated. The menu had a few unique items like Tonkotsu X and Truffle ramen, but I ultimately chose the Tonkotsu X as it was a "London exclusive". A cool feature was customizing the hardness/chewiness of the noodles, and I went with hard as they suggested. The soup was quite flavourful and hot enough, and the 3 pieces of meat were a perfect size. The only thing missing was the egg. However, all the flavours blended together beautifully and made it an enjoyable and authentic ramen eating experience. The shop is small, but there are 2 levels of seating. I would definitely eat here again, even if there was a queue.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Tonkotsu X ramen

fwnozPWnWV3w2wKoXz4E7w.text: It's very authentic tonkotsu styled broth, but unfortunately it is not to my preference. Broth is thick proving they spent a long time slow-cooking their broth. But it's too heavy! Too much pork fat that I wish they have some fruit tea on the menu to wash it down. However all they have are ramen and rice balls.Maybe a good place for others who enjoy heavy broth, but definitely not me.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Salmon rice ball
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. 14 pounds ramen. Forgot the name

sNP9qhY-aI3iwVxVZp66UQ.text: I officially LOVE Kanada-ya.Why:- The soup is truly delicious! It *is* really rich and I realise that I couldn't eat that much oily goodness every day BUT I love it.- They'll cook your noodles how you like them. (Go hard.)- The eggs cost extra, but you need them! Seriously. The eggs are so, so good. I should probably have copied Ali C and ordered two eggs - although I am not sure I'd be able to eat that much.- I could write a whole extra review about the matcha soft serve. It has a really good, strong matcha flavour, and yet somehow manages to be refreshing at the same time. - You can book a table! It's all the noodle-joy without the wait!  A while ago my friends in the boozy bunch (boozybunch.com/tag/ramen…) reviewed all of London's best ramen joints in #ramenwars and they voted Bone Daddies as the best ramen, with Kanada-ya as an honourable mention. I think they all need to come back and re-try their noodles as I am pretty sure Kanada-ya is better.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. Mix of matcha and orange ice cream
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. chicken-paitan plus a perfect egg

jOux08YcRCYXG1Oe7g3Qiw.text: The ramen are delicious and you can choose the way you like it to be cooked!!! I am only putting 4 because we were sitter downstairs and you could smell the toilets (mind that it didnt stink but just smelled like artificial perfume) so if you can try to sit upstairs. But anyhow the ramen are fresh and delicious and the broth is really tasty!!! A must go if you like ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. The original
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom. The Truffle Ramen is just delicious!!!

nAFcmoKgjgyWv6BrC9XxAQ.text: On Panton Street sits Kanada-Ya, a cosy authentic Japanese Ramen bar.My experience:My love of Japanese food never seems to ends, so last year when I was invited to review Kanada-Ya ramen bar I quickly accepted. Kanada-Ya sits in the heart of Piccadilly and is a well-known ramen bar.Upon arrival, I traditionally ordered a sake sampler, which one is supposed to consume from left to right, and the sakes became sweeter and stronger as I drank on. Firstly, was the 'Jewel brocade'- (Dewazakura Omachi Junmai Ginjo). A premium chilled sake, which is extremely flavoured with honey and sweet rice. For me, it was extremely sweet but in a distinctive way. Second from the sampler was the 'Heart of Oak' (Tamagawa Junmai)- Which is a masterpiece made by the genius British sales master Philip Harper, it was nutty and deep Umami and is to be served at room temperature.  For me, this was better than the Jewel Brocade, it was rich in sweetness but does not leave a bitter aftertaste. Finally, the Yuzu (Umenoyado Yuzu liqueur)- a refreshing Japanese and fruit sake. For me this was the best of all sakes, as the alcohol was prominent, but was sweet and cooling, this definitely was my favourite.Although Kanada-Ya is predominately known for their Ramen, I was feeling extra hungry and thought I would try out some of their small plates. Karaage is Japanese fried chicken, served with mayo. I was pleasantly surprised with the first bite as the fried chicken is soft, supple and gently breaks off in the mouth. The chicken is well seasoned and full of flavour and is served in four pieces, although I only ended up eating one piece as the Karaage is quite filling.I also tried the Kanada-Ya's Aburi Chashu, which is seared Chashu pork belly with yakiniku tare. I am a big lover of pork; especially pork belly and I could not wait to try this! The pork belly melted in my mouth and the musky but sweet taste enhanced once dipped in the provided sauce. The only issue is that some of the pork pieces were hard. I was advised to try the Tonkotsu X or Tonkotsu, which are the most popular Ramen choices at Kanada-Ya, however, I was coming down with a cold and the best way to cure a cold is with spice. Therefore, I chose the spicy Yuzu ramen; with spicy Yuzu, pork, corn-fed chicken broth, Chashu pork collar, wood ear fungus, seaweed and spring onion. The menu recommends choosing hard ramen noodles, so I went ahead with this recommendation I was worried about the wood ear fungus because I had no clue what ear fungus actually is, but all the ingredients in the dish worked well together. The ramen was full of flavour, as the taste of the spicy chicken broth has a potent taste, and is just the right amount of spice, which enabled me to still enjoy the dish. The seaweed added a more salty/savoury aftertaste to the ramen. I still had some Aburi Chashu left from my starters, so I added this to the ramen and let it soak in the broth, which aided in softening up the pork. I felt that there was not enough pork in the dish, but that is because I am a heavy meat eater, so I would advise adding extra meat as a topping.After most of the content of the ramen was gone, I shamelessly sipped on the chicken broth, which was delicious and I do believe it aided in getting rid of my cold, which is a bonus! As it was my second time trying ramen, I really enjoyed this experience and I would love to go back and try the Tonkotsu X.To refresh my palette I had a full large glass of Yuzu sake, which is very refreshing after the ramen. However, you are warned, for this sake is a silent creeper for the sake is so sweet that I did not realise the amount of alcohol I was consuming! Overall, this was a great experience for me as my second time eating ramen. Kanada-Ya is ideal if popping in on a lunch break from work, or casually eating with friends.Price: £(However, the sakes can get pricey)What to wear: Smart casual(I wore a blazer, top and trainers)Ambience: Cosy restaurant with knowledgeable staff

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom

eqhacyd4giqQaygNSC7DrQ.text: This is the 2nd branch of Kanada-Ya in London.  We should be so lucky in London as outside of London, there is only one branch of Kanada-Ya each in Hong Kong and Japan.  I only found out about this 2nd branch when I was googling the opening hours of the original branch and the website said that they have a new 2nd branch.I love this branch as there are less people and the queue is definitely shorter.  There are also more seats compared to the original branch.  I have to say that the food do come out slightly slower compared to the 1st branch but I rather sit and wait for the best ramen in town.  Since I have found out about this branch, I have stopped going to the original branch to avoid the queue and tight space.You would think that the quality of the ramen would have dropped since the place is bigger, but no.  The quality stays the same but just more space in this branch.  The staff are as friendly as ever and never ever arrogant.  As an Asian, I know for a fact that there are a lot of establishment out there where the service is basically non-existence like in Asia.  In London, some Asian establishment's employers becomes extremely arrogant and rude as they know they are the best and people will still flock in for the food.  However, it does not happen in Kanada-Ya and that is why people keeps coming here.  Best food and service. Usually, I would say go straight for the ramen as I find that the sides were not worth it.  However, the matcha soft serve ice cream here is extremely good.  The matcha flavour is very strong and they really do not hold back on it.  It is extremely expensive for the matcha powder and I am glad they make it as they do.  Finally, please order more of the hanjuku eggs.  I have always ordered 2 eggs.  If I have my way, I would order about 4 or 5 eggs.  But it would most prob not fit that well in my bowl and I'm sure I will be embarassed when my neighbour stares at me.   Oh god, marinated so well and its definitely more orgasmic than se*.

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom

msAQwfQm2qM0Z6DZxtkPGg.text: There is a reason they have won the Top 50 Ramen of Japan award. This is superior ramen, so only come here if you can appreciate it and won't settle for just any cheap bowl of dirty water.It's all about the broth and noodles, both they have mastered. Go with their recommendation for hard noodles as they will be the perfect consistency. The broth is thick and hearty but not overwhelming. I've had the truffle which is basically a mushroom soup strong in flavour so prepare yourself. I've also enjoyed the Tonkatsu X,  the pork and chicken combo that pairs nicely. My favourite is the spicy and powerful Geikkan, tanten men which has a pork broth, minced pork with a load of spice and pork slices. Mix it cautiously so you only get the right amount of spice at a time.Toppings are all on point, having tried the black garlic oil which is a great flavour addition to the base and the delicious egg is a must, prepared well to provide the best flavour and consistency of yolk to egg white ratio.Side dishes like karaage and edamame are tasty as well but you really want to come and enjoy the ramen. They even have a yuzu cold ramen if you want something different. Whatever you get will be excellent and I dare you not to return, no matter how scary the queue may be!

photos.caption: Photo of Kanada-Ya - London, United Kingdom
